comment: If White had allowed this pawn to be captured at c4, he would have been left with an isolated d-pawn. The consequences of the move actually played are even more serious, for he now gets all disadvantages which we know are associated with "blockaded security", but not its advantages. The usual advantage lies in the possiblity of an attack on the b-pawn, but in the present case, with a pawn at b7, but already on b5, this simply doesn't arise
